newsitem.title: USA: Amazon.com stock soars after IPO.
newsitem.headline: Amazon.com stock soars after IPO.

text.p: The stock of online book retailer Amazon.com Inc. surged more than 60 percent on its first day of trading Thursday, extending a rally that began even before the company went public.

Late Wednesday, Amazon.com launched an initial public offering of 3 million shares at $18 a share. Just two days earlier, lead underwriter Deutsche Morgan Grenfell had already raised the price to between $14 and $16 a share from $12 to $14 a share, reflecting healthy demand for the Internet book seller.
The stock traded Thursday at $26.75 on Nasdaq, where it was the most active issue on volume of almost 3 million shares in late morning trading.

Amazon's offering, one of the most closely watched IPOs this year, has attracted considerable attention because the Seattle-based company has been one of only a handful of companies to successfully exploit the Internet as a vehicle for commerce.
IPO analysts had expected the two-year old company to garner strong premiums, especially since technology stocks have rebounded this month after slumping earlier in the year.
The company offers more than 2.5 million titles and bills itself as the world's biggest bookstore.
On Monday, bookstore giant Barnes & Noble took issue with that description and filed a lawsuit against Amazon.com.
Barnes & Noble also launched its own Web site on Tuesday, boasting more than 1 million available books, most of which were being offered at prices that undercut Amazon's.

Amazon is growing exponentially, selling $15.7 million worth of books in 1996. It topped that in the first quarter this year, selling $16 million from its headquarters in a slightly run-down Seattle office building.
But it warned in its prosectus that such growth rates are probably "not sustainable" and said it expects to incur "substantial operating losses for the foreseeable future."

Investors are betting that with a cash infusion of some $40 million, Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos, 33, will be able to capitalise on the buzz that has made his company one of the best-known names in Internet commerce.

But Amazon.com could have a tough time beating back Barnes & Noble and other rivals. Other booksellers also are dipping into online waters, and Borders Group Inc. is expected to announce its Internet plans soon.

Amazon said it has granted the underwriters an option to purchase up to 450,000 additional shares from the company to covering over-allotments, if any. Alex. Brown Inc. and Hambrecht & Quist are co-managers in the IPO.
